timeline.bodyText: My understanding (which is not very good on this point) is that CONSUMER is used for a span that represents the processing of the message, and fetching a message from a queue synchronously like this would be CLIENT, with parent from the current Context, and a link to the producer span
timeline.author: trask
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -192,12 +190,14 @@ class JMS2Test extends AgentTestRunner {
       trace(0, 1) { // Consumer trace
         span(0) {
           parent()
-          operationName destinationType + "/" + destinationName + " receive"
-          spanKind CLIENT
+          operationName destinationName + " receive"
+          spanKind CONSUMER

replies.bodyText:
IMO this is very confusing right now: https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-specification/blob/master/specification/trace/semantic_conventions/messaging.md#span-kind
I read convention like "CONSUMER if async, CLIENT if sync and sends response back"
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText:
I think we need to clarify, because I think this change breaks this use case:

A servlet request reads a message from a queue

I would expect for the span "reading from queue" to be parented to the span "servlet request" (with a link to the "producer" span).
With this change, the span "reading from queue" is parented to the "producer" span, and is no longer in the span tree of the "servlet request".
replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText:
Setting aside that this is quite an unusual use-case for me :), I say that messaging semantic convention does not support this anyway. You see, CLIENT is a variant of PRODUCER, it means an operation creating a new message. Thus receive operation cannot be CLIENT. It can be either CONSUMER or SERVER :)
And I think you are mixing two separate things here: setting span's kind and parent/link. They are mostly independent from each other.
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText: This PR changes both the span kind and the parent/link behavior. I disagree with both changes 😂 but am very likely wrong about one or more likely both. I added to tomorrow's agenda, and in case there's still disagreement after that, we can merge as is and escalate spec clarification.
replies.author: trask

timeline.author: trask

timeline.bodyText: Are these only used as string constants? If so string constants in JMSTracer seems more natural
timeline.author: trask
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,23 @@

+ * limitations under the License.

+
+package io.opentelemetry.instrumentation.auto.jms;
+
+public enum Operation {
+  send,
+  receive,
+  process
+}

replies.bodyText: Having string input parameter allows for passing any string. In this case only these 3 values are allowed by convention.
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText:
Makes sense 👍
Btw, the lowercase enum names are throwing me a bit, can we change to SEND("send")? I think that's more conventional.
replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText: Can I answer you "no"? :) The "convention" to have enum elements all in uppercase baffles me. Why should we wrap desired values (lowercase in this case as per spec) in identical uppercase strings? What benefit that brings?
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText:
The "convention" to have enum elements all in uppercase baffles me

Curious if you disagree that it is conventional for enums to be uppercase in Java? Or if you disagree that we should follow this convention?
The point of following convention is that it helps people reading the code. When I see Operation.send in code, it looks like direct non-constant field access, and takes me more time to understand than it's worth.
Also we document in CONTRIBUTING.md that we follow Google Java Style Guide so would suggest we lean on that for style / convention questions where possible.
Happy to accept @anuraaga as tie-breaker vote either way though 👍😄
replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText:
I find strange the notion "constants should be UPPERCASE in Java". But in general that is indeed, not important and we should just follow coding style.
But it is more important, IMO, when such coding style forces clumsier design. And I think that SEND("send") is clumsy.
replies.author: iNikem

timeline.bodyText: same method level comment suggestion as above
timeline.author: trask

timeline.bodyText: Why do we need to specify start timestamp to current time ourselves here?
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: It is used later in onConsume method to calculate record.queue_time_ms
replies.author: iNikem

timeline.message: Update parents as per spec proposal
